body.p: Ant. New Orleans, January 19, 1865.
Editor of the "Occident", Philadelphai.

DEAR SIR: There is, perhaps, no country in the world
where the Hebrew communities are so frequently increased by
numbers of proselytes, as in this country; and our trans-
antlantic bretheren must surely, when they learn from the
different American Jewish periodicals these happy tidings,
greatly rejoice, and think the time of the advent of the
Messiah is nigh, truth commences to dawn over the Gentiles,
and break the long night of ignorance and superstition, and
fill their hearts, as prophesied, with the fear of God, and
the true knowledge of His unity, whilst we here are, to our
deepest regret, convinced that it is not God, but the "altar
of God," to which these proselytes are coming. To find or
please a husband whom they love, the daughters of the Gentiles
join our nation, but by no means our religion; and we must not
deceive ourselves, since we are convinced in our heart that
it is not the power of truth but the sharp arrows of Cupid to
which this rapid increase of our nation, by the sons and daugh-
ters of Edom, is to be attributed; for, as heedlessly as they
often run away from the fatherhouse, following the man of their
choice, without the consent and blessing of their parents, so
they abandon, yet with much less scruple, their church, kneel-
ing down at the altar of the Synagogue, where the heedless
maiden expects to be united to the subject of her love.

Reverend sir, by writing this, I do not intend to blame
either the proselytes or those who admitted them into the
covenant of Abraham. תושחלתע it is now a time, when to be
silent is the best and wiseest policy; we must see and hear

much and be silent, we see them every day converting Jews
into Gentiles, our hearts break . תושחלתע it is now a time, when to be, but our lips
are mute and we are silent; why should we not be silent when
Gentiles are converted into Jews? I merely intend to con-
quer the erroneous idea of our people in general, who believe
that the making of proselytes is one of the most God-pleas-
ing actions that can be performed, though, in fact, even if
everything is done in full accordance with the law, it cannot
be regarded as a Hebrew. We are permitted by law to admit
Gentiles into the covenant of Abraham, under certain con-
ditions; this, however, is only a permission Hebrew but not a
Hebrew.

Let me, therefore, exhibit before your readers several
passages, by which I may show them what the Talmud thinks
of proselytes in general:

1. Yebamoth, 109. Says Rabbi Yitzchak, Hebrew
Hebrew Misfortune after misfortune shall befall
those who admit Gentiles into the covenant of Abraham; to
which Tossephoth remarks, though it seems to be a Hebrew to
make Hebrew, for, if otherwise, Jehoshua would not have con-
verted Rahab, and Hillel would not have complied with the
desire of the two heathens to be converted, still these are
but exceptional cases. Jehoshua knew from the character of
Rahab, and so knew Hillel, that they would one day be strict
and faithful Jews, Hebrew:

2. Kiddushim, 70. Says Rabbi ChHelbo: Leprosy is not
so hurtful to the body as proselytes are to the cause of
Judaism, Hebrew, Rashi gives the reason—
Hebrew:
3. Niddah, 11. The proselytes in Israel prevent the coming
of the Messiah, Hebrew:

4. Abodah Zarah, 3. In the days of David and Solomon pro-
selytes were not accepted; no admission into the covenant
was then granted to Gentiles. Though we find that in the
days of Solomon, over 150,000 heathens embraced the Jewish
religion, these, however, says Rabboi Yochanan, Yebamoth 79,
were but Hebrew, which means, as Rashi explains, they
made themselves Jews, embraced our religion, but were never
accepted or acknowledged as such by our nation, Hebrew
Hebrew: A similar case is found in Esther, Hebrew
Hebrew the word Hebrew in the Hebrew
says distinctly they made themselves Jews, but were not
accepted or acknowledged as such by the nation.

5. Sanhedrin, 99. Says Rabbi Azzay: Timnah was a
princess, the daughter of a king, desirous to become a Jew-
ess, she went for that purpose to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob,
who all refused (not to convert her but) to admit her into
the covenant, and recognise her as a member of their family;
she then went and became Hebrew, and said:
I prefer to be a servant-maid in that nation, than to be a
princess of any other, Hebrew
Hebrew:

From all these different quoatations, we can sufficeient-
ly see that our sages were never in favor of making prosel-
ytes, and when Rabbi Eliezer, Pessachim 78, says Hebrew
Hebrew, he does not mean to say that
Israel shall make proselytes; for if so, he had better say Hebrew
Hebrew or Hebrew, but the word Hebrew refers to the
preceding word, Hebrew, and the whole idea is but this; Israel

was driven from their country to live with the many different
nations of the earth, only for the great purpose to spread
the name and unity of God all over the earth, to light the
light of God wherever there is darkness, and, through us,
all the nations of the earth shall know that there is but
one God.

There is, to my knowledge, but one passage which
speaks more favorably of the admission of Hebrew to Judaism,
and this is the Hebrew Section Hebrew, where we read as
follows, Hebrew:
What opinion had our sages of proselytes?
A very unfavorable one!

6. Pessachim, 112, we read—Rabbi Yehudah Judah Hannassi
enjoined upon his children, before he died, that none of his
family should intermarry with proselytes, Hebrew
Hebrew *Hebrew In Midrash Yalkut Hebrew, we read: Rabbi ChHiyah said
"Do not trust proselytes, have no confidence in their piety,
neither in that of their children, Hebrew
Hebrew. This unfavorable opinion
we find justified in Sabbath, 33, by Hebrew, the
son of proselytes, (his father and mother were proselytes—
Rashyi,) who denounced Rabbi Simon ben Yochayi before the king,
in consequence of which the latter was compelled to save his
life by a hasty flight to a cavern, wherein he remained hidden
twelve years; and when, after the death of the king, he left
the cavern and met the denunciator Hebrew, he said—
Hebrew.

* When Rabby J. died, his four sons were already married,
therefore we translate Hebrew his family.

Here I beg leave to remark, that, when we meet the very
same Hebrew again in the Moed Katoan, 9, as the name
of a great man to whom Rabbi Simeon ben Yochayi sends his
son to request his blessing, it is merely a misprint, and
instead of Hebrew, it ought to be Hebrew,
mentioned in Talmud Jerusalem Taanith, sect. 2d: Hebrew
Hebrew (see Mateh Mosheth,
who also assumes as most probable that this Hebrew is
the same Hebrew of Moed Katoan to whom Rabbi Simeon ben
Yochayi sent his son to be blessed).

From different other places in the Talmud, we learn that
it was always regarded as an insult to be called "Son of a
Proselyte," see Yoma, 71, Hebrew.

The rank of proselyte was inferior to that of a Hebrew
or Hebrew, he was next to a freed slave. — See Mishnah Horayth
13, Hebrew.

We find that when Ezra found out that many Israelites
who came up with him from Babylon to Jerusalem lived with
Hebrew, he ordered them to be sent away with their
children, and so they did. Why did he give them such a
cruel command, could they not, as many in similar cases are
doing now, make their wives Jewesses, or at least let the
children be circumcised and stay with their fathers? Surely
for no other reason than this that Ezra did not want to dis-
grace the nation by making such proselytes and sport with the
holy Word of God, and make by-ways and side-doors to the
sacred edifice of our holy religion, that every one may
smuggle himself in and our whatever he pleases, and thus suit
every one's way of thinking, as Iben Ezra to Ezra vi. explains,
Hebrew.

Hoping that this may cause our people to change their
opinion concerning proselytes, I remain, dear sir,
Most respectfully yours,
DR. ILLOWY.
